title: Blood Pressure Pills
question_text: A doctor has developed a new pill to hopefully lower her patients blood pressure. She recruits $30$ patients and prescribes them the new pill. The new patients are not told to keep their diet and exercise routine the same. Can the doctor be certain the pill helps lower blood pressure?

choices.text: No, because the people are not random.
No, because we cannot be sure if it's the pill or other factors that help lower the blood pressure.
Yes, because the doctor developed the pill.
Yes, if the results show a decrease in blood pressure.
Yes, as she can compare person to person.

solution:
The doctor is putting together a study in order to collect data about her new weight loss pill. The hope is that after collecting the data, she would be able to make a conclusion with certainty about whether the pill helped lower blood pressure.

But, the doctor did not take into account the outside factors that might lower blood pressure that aren't her pill. Since she did not tell her patients to keep the rest of their lives the same, she cannot be sure whether he pill lowered the blood pressure, or the other factors. Therefore, we are unsure whether the data we collected is accurate.

Choice 'B' is correct.
